text.p: We've noted that a linear transformation has an inverse if and only if it is both into and onto. Let's recall our results about when a linear transformation from [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^ n[/mathjaxinline] to [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^ m[/mathjaxinline] can or must be into or onto.
Suppose [mathjaxinline]T: \mathbb R^ n \rightarrow \mathbb R^ m[/mathjaxinline] is a linear transformation.
If [mathjaxinline]n<m[/mathjaxinline], what can we conclude about [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline]?

optioninput.options: ('T must be into','T might be into, or might not','T cannot be into')
optioninput.correct: T might be into, or might not

optioninput.options: ('T must be onto','T might be onto, or might not','T cannot be onto')

text.p: If [mathjaxinline]n>m[/mathjaxinline], what can we conclude about [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline]?

optioninput.options: ('T must be into','T might be into, or might not','T cannot be into')
('T must be onto','T might be onto, or might not','T cannot be onto')
optioninput.correct: T might be onto, or might not
